review.title: Identifying Condition-Action Statements in Medical Guidelines Using Domain-Independent Features
review.abstract: This paper advances the state of the art in text understanding of medical guidelines by releasing two new annotated clinical guidelines datasets, and establishing baselines for using machine learning to extract condition-action pairs. In contrast to prior work that relies on manually created rules, we report experiment with several supervised machine learning techniques to classify sentences as to whether they express conditions and actions. We show the limitations and possible extensions of this work on text mining of medical guidelines.

sections.heading: Condition-Action Extraction
sections.text: In this paper, we propose an automated process to find and extract statements about a patient's condition, using NLP tools and concepts to achieve more general models; we define the task as a classification task; in the face of an input explanation, we classify it into one of three categories: NC (no condition) if the statement has no condition; CA, if the statement is a conditional sentence; and CC (condition sequence) if the statement has a condition that has no effect; for a CDSS, both "what is true" about a patient and "what to do" with a patient; CC and CA statements can be merged into one conditional sentence. There are limitations in this specification of classification categories. For example, guidelines may contain statements that relate to one condition, in another explanation, or sentences that are appropriate for different cases.

sections.text: We use three medical guidelines to create Gold Standard Data Sets. They provide statements, tables, and numbers about hypertension, rhinosinusitis, and asthma. The creation of Gold Standard Data Sets is detailed below. Our data delivery process went like this: We started converting the guidelines from PDF or HTML format, using sentences only to address conversion errors. sections.heading: Model Performance
sections.text: Hypertension, asthma and rhinosinusitis guidelines and gold standard data sets were used to evaluate our model. As two of these commented corpora are new, our model establishes a baseline. The asthma corpus was previously examined by (Wenzina and Kaiser 2013). We extract candidate statements by applying the above regex tags. Hypertension, asthma and rhinosinusitis guidelines had 278, 172 and 761 candidate statements. By applying this filter subtask, we get rid of 38, 116 and 5 condition statements each from guidelines. We used Weka (Hall et al. 2009) classifiers to create our models. ZeroR, Nave Bayes, J48 and random forest classifiers were used in our project.

sections.heading: Conclusions and Future Work
sections.text: We investigated the problem of automated extraction of conditional actions from clinical guidelines based on a commented corpus, p. 43. We proposed a simple supervised model that classifies statements based on combinations of some of the talking marks used as characteristics. We showed results from classifiers who use this model on three different annotated data sets that we have created. We publish these data sets for others to use. Obviously, this is a very preliminary work. Our work established foundations for automated extraction of conditional rules from medical guidelines, but their performance is still worse than a collection of manually created extraction rules. To fill this gap, we are currently expanding our model with semantic information along the lines (Kaiser, Seyfang, and Miksch 2011) and (Kaiser 2013). In addition, we are starting experiments with some discourse relationships - these are important, for example, in understanding lists and tables.
